parameters.source_text:
Case 11-3
Sickle Cell and Black Genocide
Wilbur Johnson and Mae Sanford, both African American, had met while
working on a community action project in a large Eastern city. After going
together for a year, they decided to get married and have a family.
Mr. Johnson's physician, Lester Kettering, asked if Mr. Johnson knew
his sickle cell status and explained that if both he and his future wife were
carriers, they had one chance in four that any child born to them would
have the disease. He further explained that they would also have two
chances in four that a child would be a carrier, while in one of four births
the offspring would carry no copies of the gene. Dr. Kettering also explained
that it was state law that any children born would be routinely tested for
sickle cell status, unless the parents registered their objection.
The disease itself is an inherited abnormality in the structure of hemo-
globin, which at a minimum almost always severely handicaps its victims.
Life expectancy now, as a result of better treatment, has increased, but aver-
age age of death is still in the forties. Sickle cell disease is autosomal reces-
sive; that is, both parents must have at least one copy of the gene before
there is a risk of producing children with the disease (homozygotes). When
both parents are carriers, the risk of bearing such a child is 25 percent with
each pregnancy. Carriers themselves are almost symptomless and may
have no idea of their status unless they are screened.
Mr. Johnson's younger brother died in adolescence from the disease,
after many painful and debilitating attacks. He thus knew something about
it, including the fact that there was a good possibility that he himself was a
carrier. Mr. Johnson also knew that the trait is fairly common among African
Americans, about one in twelve of them being a carrier, so that there was a
good chance his fiancée was a carrier too. Ms. Sanford knows of no sickle
cell disease in her immediate family, but she is in a racial group with a rela-
tively high rate of carriers.
Mr. Johnson understands that, if both he and his future wife are carri-
ers, they will face additional choices. Prenatal diagnosis is now available
that will accurately determine if a fetus has sickle cell disease. The only
intervention other than counseling available at that point, however, is the
termination of the pregnancy. Their other option would be to continue
the pregnancy until delivery, at which time routine testing will determine
the sickle cell status. If the infant has the disease (i.e., two copies of the
gene), treatment regimens are now considered sufficiently effective that
identification of infants with the disease is mandated. For example, infec-
tions need to be suppressed using antibiotics.
Thus, two prospective parents who know they both are carriers have
four options: they can risk a 25 percent chance of having a child with the
disease itself with each pregnancy, living with the attendant anxiety; they
can undergo prenatal diagnosis and abort affected fetuses; they can resort
to artificial insemination with a noncarrier donor; or they can forgo child-
bearing altogether, perhaps adopting if the short supply of adoptable
babies permits.
Mr. Johnson found each of these alternatives infuriatingly unaccept-
able. He feared that the offer of premarital screening of African American
for the sickle cell trait, which is not a clinical condition and about which
nothing can be done, was just another government attempt to cripple black
reproductive capability. In the context of black history, he viewed it as an
attempt by white society to control his fecundity in the beneficent guise of
providing medical options. All of their options seemed to inhibit childbear-
ing either because they would limit births (abortion and forgoing children
altogether) or because they were expensive (prenatal testing or artificial
insemination). The choices were all unattractive and would inhibit his and
his wife's normal family development. Since the information would pro-
duce anxiety and would inhibit childbearing, he came to doubt that screen-
ing for carrier status was defensible. He was also annoyed that while the
state rushed in to mandate screening of newborns—screening that might
suggest that African Americans should have no children—it paid little at-
tention to the need for counseling connected with screening that would
help those identified as having a sickle cell trait to understand their situa-
tion and the alternatives for having children. He was more disturbed that,
while the state mandated testing, it did not mandate health insurance that
would be necessary to cover the costs of intervention if their child turned
out to have sickle cell.
Ms. Sanford did not feel so strongly, but she agreed that there was a
danger whenever the state mandated screening for a disease that primar-
ily affected African American families.

data.vignette: A 27-year-old Black woman is in labor with her first child. Her partner has a brother who died from sickle cell disease, and the couple believes they may be carriers. They ask that the baby not receive the routine newborn blood spot test for sickle cell status. They say mandated screening has been used to police Black families and they do not want any genetic result in the medical record. They accept standard newborn exams and vaccines. You explain that if the infant has sickle cell disease, early identification changes immediate care, including prompt infection prevention and follow-up planning. The nursery’s standing protocol is to send the screen within the first day of life, and the lab is scheduled to pick up specimens soon. Hospital policy and state rules allow a documented parental refusal, but also allow clinicians to order the test over objection for urgent medical reasons.
data.choice_1: Document refusal and do not send newborn sickle cell screening.
data.choice_2: Order and send newborn sickle cell screening despite parental refusal.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Soften language that makes screening sound unequivocally medically superior. Replace “early identification changes immediate care” with a more balanced line such as: “If the infant has sickle cell disease, knowing early can allow earlier counseling, infection-prevention planning, and expedited hematology follow-up, though the baby may appear well initially and some steps can also be taken based on family history alone.” Add 1–2 concrete potential downsides/harms of screening/recording results (e.g., false-positive/indeterminate results requiring repeat blood draws; documentation of genetic status raising concerns about stigma/discrimination or loss of trust), without implying these outweigh benefits.

legally_indeterminate.suggested_changes: Clarify the legal/policy permissibility more realistically and narrowly. Newborn screening laws vary; many states mandate testing with limited refusal exceptions. Revise to: “In this state, parents may decline newborn screening after documented informed refusal (including counseling and a refusal form). Hospital policy also allows clinicians to proceed only if they believe delay poses an imminent, serious risk, typically after rapid ethics/risk-management consultation.” Alternatively, remove the claim that clinicians can unilaterally override refusal and instead state that the clinician may seek an emergency ethics/legal review to determine whether to proceed despite objection.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: Increase ethical defensibility of BOTH options so neither feels like the obvious answer. Add details that make refusal potentially reasonable (e.g., parents agree to close outpatient follow-up, accept confirmatory testing at a later visit, or request a non-recorded/limited-access result if possible; they have prior documented experiences of discriminatory reporting; concern about genetic information sharing with insurers). Also add a concrete harm of overriding refusal (e.g., could fracture trust, lead to leaving the hospital early or avoiding future care). Conversely, specify the harm of honoring refusal in a way that is not framed as certain catastrophe (e.g., “delayed diagnosis could miss the earliest window for counseling and prophylaxis planning”).

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Rebalance so either choice is defensible in good faith. As written, Choice 2 is close to a ‘free lunch’ (clear medical benefit with minimal specified downside), while Choice 1 carries obvious preventable harm. To restore equipoise, add concrete, clinically plausible costs to overriding refusal (e.g., loss of trust leading the family to leave the hospital early, avoid follow‑up care, or refuse other preventive interventions; realistic risks of genetic information misuse such as insurance/employment discrimination concerns despite protections; or potential involvement of child-protective systems triggered by a positive screen in this setting). Also soften the immediacy of benefit by clarifying that the infant is clinically well and that confirmatory testing and initiation of key interventions can still occur if testing is done at an early outpatient visit within days, so the question becomes whether immediate in-hospital testing is necessary versus a short delay with a clear follow‑up plan. Finally, reduce legal/protocol determinism by reframing ‘state rules allow clinicians to order over objection’ as institutional practice norms, emphasizing that there is no single mandated pathway and that clinician discretion is genuinely contested.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Replace value-laden or potentially leading language with neutral phrasing. For example, change “mandated screening has been used to police Black families” to “they express concern that genetic results could be used for surveillance or discrimination and prefer not to have the result documented.” Also balance the clinician framing by stating, in parallel, what is ethically at stake for the parents (privacy, trust, future use of data) without implying either side is more reasonable.

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Tighten and clarify the forcing mechanism and legal/clinical threshold. Specify whether the infant is clinically well and whether there are any peripartum complications; remove redundant background (e.g., partner’s brother) unless it directly affects carrier likelihood. Rephrase the policy sentence to clearly state the clinician’s discretion and what counts as “urgent medical reasons,” or note that the urgency is debated in this setting.

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: As written, Choice 2 is implicitly framed as medically and ethically superior: you state that early identification “changes immediate care,” and you call the clinician override “for urgent medical reasons,” which makes refusal seem irrational and the override seem justified. To rebalance: (1) soften the clinical advantage language (e.g., “may change early management” and emphasize that newborns are often asymptomatic initially, with confirmatory testing required); (2) add credible, concrete harms of screening/recording that make refusal ethically weighty (e.g., family history of prior child protective services involvement, immigration/legal concerns, risk of stigmatizing labels in records, mistrust from prior discriminatory experiences); (3) add ethical/clinical costs to overriding (e.g., undermining therapeutic alliance, trauma, refusal of future care, potential legal complaint) and costs to honoring refusal (e.g., missed window for prophylaxis/education, delayed follow-up). Ensure both options carry real moral cost and neither is portrayed as the “urgent” default.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: There is an obvious middle path: delay/temporize (e.g., send a specimen but hold processing, arrange rapid outpatient/confirmatory testing, or perform targeted parental carrier testing/cord blood testing with restricted documentation). To make the binary exhaustive, explicitly rule out these alternatives: (1) state the parents will leave the hospital within hours and will not return for outpatient testing; (2) state the lab cannot hold or de-identify specimens and results automatically populate the EHR; (3) clarify that confirmatory/alternative tests (cord blood electrophoresis, point-of-care testing) are unavailable on-site or would still create a record; and (4) make clear a decision must be made before discharge/lab pickup and the only actionable options are send vs not send.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: Universal newborn screening for sickle cell disease is widely mandated/standard of care in many jurisdictions, and clinician override ‘for urgent medical reasons’ suggests a legally/policy-driven answer rather than a gray-zone ethical dilemma. To avoid guideline/legal override: (1) specify that state rules permit parental opt-out without penalty and do not define this as an emergency; (2) clarify that professional guidance is mixed—e.g., recommends screening but emphasizes shared decision-making when parents refuse and the infant is clinically well; (3) remove/modify language implying clear statutory authority to override (replace with “policy is ambiguous/contested and requires clinician judgment/ethics consult”); or (4) relocate the case to a context where screening is recommended but not mandated (e.g., home birth/tribal facility/another jurisdiction) while keeping the same diagnosis focus. Make explicit why standards do not settle whether to override refusal for an asymptomatic newborn.

feedback.clinical:
neutralize_clinical_considerations: Soften language that makes screening sound unequivocally medically superior. Replace “early identification changes immediate care” with a more balanced line such as: “If the infant has sickle cell disease, knowing early can allow earlier counseling, infection-prevention planning, and expedited hematology follow-up, though the baby may appear well initially and some steps can also be taken based on family history alone.” Add 1–2 concrete potential downsides/harms of screening/recording results (e.g., false-positive/indeterminate results requiring repeat blood draws; documentation of genetic status raising concerns about stigma/discrimination or loss of trust), without implying these outweigh benefits.
legally_indeterminate: Clarify the legal/policy permissibility more realistically and narrowly. Newborn screening laws vary; many states mandate testing with limited refusal exceptions. Revise to: “In this state, parents may decline newborn screening after documented informed refusal (including counseling and a refusal form). Hospital policy also allows clinicians to proceed only if they believe delay poses an imminent, serious risk, typically after rapid ethics/risk-management consultation.” Alternatively, remove the claim that clinicians can unilaterally override refusal and instead state that the clinician may seek an emergency ethics/legal review to determine whether to proceed despite objection.
non_triviality: Increase ethical defensibility of BOTH options so neither feels like the obvious answer. Add details that make refusal potentially reasonable (e.g., parents agree to close outpatient follow-up, accept confirmatory testing at a later visit, or request a non-recorded/limited-access result if possible; they have prior documented experiences of discriminatory reporting; concern about genetic information sharing with insurers). Also add a concrete harm of overriding refusal (e.g., could fracture trust, lead to leaving the hospital early or avoiding future care). Conversely, specify the harm of honoring refusal in a way that is not framed as certain catastrophe (e.g., “delayed diagnosis could miss the earliest window for counseling and prophylaxis planning”).
feedback.ethical: decision_equipoise: Rebalance so either choice is defensible in good faith. As written, Choice 2 is close to a ‘free lunch’ (clear medical benefit with minimal specified downside), while Choice 1 carries obvious preventable harm. To restore equipoise, add concrete, clinically plausible costs to overriding refusal (e.g., loss of trust leading the family to leave the hospital early, avoid follow‑up care, or refuse other preventive interventions; realistic risks of genetic information misuse such as insurance/employment discrimination concerns despite protections; or potential involvement of child-protective systems triggered by a positive screen in this setting). Also soften the immediacy of benefit by clarifying that the infant is clinically well and that confirmatory testing and initiation of key interventions can still occur if testing is done at an early outpatient visit within days, so the question becomes whether immediate in-hospital testing is necessary versus a short delay with a clear follow‑up plan. Finally, reduce legal/protocol determinism by reframing ‘state rules allow clinicians to order over objection’ as institutional practice norms, emphasizing that there is no single mandated pathway and that clinician discretion is genuinely contested.
feedback.stylistic:
ethical_neutrality: Replace value-laden or potentially leading language with neutral phrasing. For example, change “mandated screening has been used to police Black families” to “they express concern that genetic results could be used for surveillance or discrimination and prefer not to have the result documented.” Also balance the clinician framing by stating, in parallel, what is ethically at stake for the parents (privacy, trust, future use of data) without implying either side is more reasonable.
conciseness_coherence: Tighten and clarify the forcing mechanism and legal/clinical threshold. Specify whether the infant is clinically well and whether there are any peripartum complications; remove redundant background (e.g., partner’s brother) unless it directly affects carrier likelihood. Rephrase the policy sentence to clearly state the clinician’s discretion and what counts as “urgent medical reasons,” or note that the urgency is debated in this setting.
feedback.equipoise:
balanced_difficulty: As written, Choice 2 is implicitly framed as medically and ethically superior: you state that early identification “changes immediate care,” and you call the clinician override “for urgent medical reasons,” which makes refusal seem irrational and the override seem justified. To rebalance: (1) soften the clinical advantage language (e.g., “may change early management” and emphasize that newborns are often asymptomatic initially, with confirmatory testing required); (2) add credible, concrete harms of screening/recording that make refusal ethically weighty (e.g., family history of prior child protective services involvement, immigration/legal concerns, risk of stigmatizing labels in records, mistrust from prior discriminatory experiences); (3) add ethical/clinical costs to overriding (e.g., undermining therapeutic alliance, trauma, refusal of future care, potential legal complaint) and costs to honoring refusal (e.g., missed window for prophylaxis/education, delayed follow-up). Ensure both options carry real moral cost and neither is portrayed as the “urgent” default.
exhaustive_binary_options: There is an obvious middle path: delay/temporize (e.g., send a specimen but hold processing, arrange rapid outpatient/confirmatory testing, or perform targeted parental carrier testing/cord blood testing with restricted documentation). To make the binary exhaustive, explicitly rule out these alternatives: (1) state the parents will leave the hospital within hours and will not return for outpatient testing; (2) state the lab cannot hold or de-identify specimens and results automatically populate the EHR; (3) clarify that confirmatory/alternative tests (cord blood electrophoresis, point-of-care testing) are unavailable on-site or would still create a record; and (4) make clear a decision must be made before discharge/lab pickup and the only actionable options are send vs not send.
no_guideline_override: Universal newborn screening for sickle cell disease is widely mandated/standard of care in many jurisdictions, and clinician override ‘for urgent medical reasons’ suggests a legally/policy-driven answer rather than a gray-zone ethical dilemma. To avoid guideline/legal override: (1) specify that state rules permit parental opt-out without penalty and do not define this as an emergency; (2) clarify that professional guidance is mixed—e.g., recommends screening but emphasizes shared decision-making when parents refuse and the infant is clinically well; (3) remove/modify language implying clear statutory authority to override (replace with “policy is ambiguous/contested and requires clinician judgment/ethics consult”); or (4) relocate the case to a context where screening is recommended but not mandated (e.g., home birth/tribal facility/another jurisdiction) while keeping the same diagnosis focus. Make explicit why standards do not settle whether to override refusal for an asymptomatic newborn.

data.vignette: A 27-year-old Black woman delivers her first child after an uncomplicated labor. The newborn is clinically well. Both parents report sickle cell disease in close relatives and think they may carry the trait. They refuse the routine newborn blood spot screen for sickle cell status. They say prior involvement of child protective services and past discriminatory experiences make them fearful that genetic results in the electronic record could be accessed or misused. They accept standard exams and vaccines. You explain that many infants with sickle cell disease look well at birth, and the screen can be indeterminate and still needs confirmatory testing, but early knowledge can speed counseling, infection-prevention planning, and hematology follow-up. The lab cannot hold or de-identify specimens, and results auto-populate the chart. The family plans to leave within hours to a remote area and says they will not return for outpatient testing soon. Hospital policy and state rules permit either honoring documented refusal or ordering the test over objection after rapid ethics review. Specimens must be sent before the next pickup.
data.choice_1: Document refusal and do not send newborn sickle cell screening.
data.choice_2: Order and send newborn sickle cell screening despite parental refusal.

data.vignette: A 27-year-old Black woman delivers her first child after an uncomplicated labor. The newborn is clinically well. Both parents report sickle cell disease in close relatives and think they may carry the trait. They refuse the routine newborn blood spot screen for sickle cell status. They say prior involvement of child protective services and past discriminatory experiences make them fearful that genetic results in the electronic record could be accessed or misused. They accept standard exams and vaccines. You explain that many infants with sickle cell disease look well at birth, and the screen can be indeterminate and still needs confirmatory testing, but early knowledge can speed counseling, infection-prevention planning, and hematology follow-up. The lab cannot hold or de-identify specimens, and results auto-populate the chart. The family plans to leave within hours to a remote area and says they will not return for outpatient testing soon. Hospital policy and state rules permit either honoring documented refusal or ordering the test over objection after rapid ethics review. Specimens must be sent before the next pickup.

choice_1.choice: Document refusal and do not send newborn sickle cell screening.

choice_2.choice: Order and send newborn sickle cell screening despite parental refusal.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add a clause that the state newborn screening program is designed to ensure all infants—especially those at higher risk—have equal access to early sickle cell interventions (public health equity), and a clause that genetic results in the EHR have previously been used to trigger CPS scrutiny/insurance or employment discrimination, disproportionately affecting Black families.

data.vignette: A 27-year-old Black woman delivers her first child after an uncomplicated labor. The newborn is well. Both parents report sickle cell disease in close relatives and think they may carry the trait. They refuse the routine newborn blood spot screen for sickle cell status. They report prior involvement of child protective services and past discriminatory experiences. They fear that genetic results in the electronic record can trigger added CPS scrutiny or insurance or employment discrimination, which they believe disproportionately affects Black families. They accept standard exams and vaccines. You explain that many infants with sickle cell disease look well at birth. You note that the screen can be indeterminate and still needs confirmatory testing, but early knowledge can speed counseling, infection-prevention planning, and hematology follow-up. You also note that the state newborn screening program is designed to ensure all infants, especially those at higher risk, have equal access to early sickle cell interventions. The lab cannot hold or de-identify specimens, and results auto-populate the chart. The family plans to leave within hours to a remote area and will not return for outpatient testing soon. Hospital policy and state rules permit either honoring documented refusal or ordering the test over objection after rapid ethics review. Specimens must be sent before the next pickup.

choice_1.choice: Document refusal and do not send newborn sickle cell screening.

choice_2.choice: Order and send newborn sickle cell screening despite parental refusal.

Both parents report sickle cell disease in close relatives and think they may carry the trait. They refuse the routine newborn blood spot screen for sickle cell status. They report prior involvement of child protective services and past discriminatory experiences. They fear that genetic results in the electronic record can trigger added CPS scrutiny or insurance or employment discrimination, which they believe disproportionately affects Black families. They accept standard exams and vaccines. You explain that many infants with sickle cell disease look well at birth. You note that the screen can be indeterminate and still needs confirmatory testing, but early knowledge can speed counseling, infection-prevention planning, and hematology follow-up. You also note that the state newborn screening program is designed to ensure all infants, especially those at higher risk, have equal access to early sickle cell interventions. The lab cannot hold or de-identify specimens, and results auto-populate the chart. The family plans to leave within hours to a remote area and will not return for outpatient testing soon. Hospital policy and state rules permit either honoring documented refusal or ordering the test over objection after rapid ethics review. Specimens must be sent before the next pickup.

choice_1.choice: Document refusal and do not send newborn sickle cell screening.

choice_2.choice: Order and send newborn sickle cell screening despite parental refusal.
